<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Indicate by check mark whether the registrants (1)&nbsp;have filed all reports required to be filed
by Section&nbsp;13 or </I><I>15(d)</I><I> of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 during the preceding 12&nbsp;months (or
for such shorter period that the registrants were required to file such reports), and (2)&nbsp;have been
subject to such filing requirements for the past 90&nbsp;days. Yes </I><FONT face="Wingdings">&#254;</FONT><I> No </I><FONT face="Wingdings">&#111;</FONT>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Indicate by check
mark whether the registrant is an accelerated filer (as defined by Rule&nbsp;12b-2 of the Securities
Exchange Act of 1934).</I>
</DIV>
<DIV align="center">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>CAUTIONARY STATEMENT REGARDING FORWARD-LOOKING INFORMATION</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;This Quarterly Report on Form 10-Q contains forward-looking statements. Forward-looking
statements include, among other things, statements concerning the strategic goals for Southern
Company&#146;s wholesale business, retail sales growth, storm damage cost recovery and repairs,
environmental regulations and expenditures, financing activities, completion of construction
projects, impacts of adoption of new accounting rules, access to sources of capital, and estimated
construction and other expenditures. In some cases, forward-looking statements can be identified by
terminology such as &#147;may,&#148; &#147;will,&#148; &#147;could,&#148; &#147;should,&#148; &#147;expects,&#148; &#147;plans,&#148; &#147;anticipates,&#148;
&#147;believes,&#148; &#147;estimates,&#148; &#147;projects,&#148; &#147;predicts,&#148; &#147;potential,&#148; or &#147;continue&#148; or the negative of
these terms or other similar terminology. There are various factors that could cause actual results
to differ materially from those suggested by the forward-looking statements; accordingly, there can
be no assurance that such indicated results will be realized. These factors include
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>the impact of recent and future federal and state regulatory change, including legislative and
regulatory initiatives regarding deregulation and restructuring of the electric utility industry, and also
changes in environmental, tax, and other laws and regulations to which Southern Company and its
subsidiaries are subject, as well as changes in application of existing laws and regulations;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>current and future litigation, regulatory investigations, proceedings, or inquiries, including the
pending EPA civil actions against certain Southern Company subsidiaries, FERC matters, IRS audits, and
Mirant related matters;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>the effects, extent, and timing of the entry of additional competition in the markets in which
Southern Company&#146;s subsidiaries operate;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>variations in demand for electricity and gas, including those relating to weather, the general
economy and population, and business growth (and declines);</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>available sources and costs of fuels;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>ability to control costs;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>

</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>

</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>

competitive prices;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>

the August&nbsp;2003 power outage in the Northeast;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>

</TABLE>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>The registrants expressly disclaim any obligation to update any forward-looking statements.</B>
</DIV>



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">6
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">12
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">














<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left">
<A name="108"></A>
</DIV>
<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF</DIV>


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</DIV>



<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt">THIRD QUARTER 2005 vs. THIRD QUARTER 2004<BR>
AND<BR>
YEAR-TO-DATE 2005 vs. YEAR-TO-DATE 2004
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>OVERVIEW</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Discussion of the results of operations is focused on Southern Company&#146;s primary business of
electricity sales in the Southeast by the retail operating companies &#150; Alabama Power, Georgia
Power, Gulf Power, Mississippi Power, and Savannah Electric &#150; and Southern Power. Southern Power
is an electric wholesale generation subsidiary with market-based rate authority. Southern
Company&#146;s other business activities include investments in synthetic fuels and leveraged lease
projects, telecommunications, energy-related services, and natural gas marketing. For additional
information on these businesses, see BUSINESS &#150; The SOUTHERN System &#150; &#147;Retail Operating Companies,&#148;
&#147;Southern Power,&#148; and &#147;Other Business&#148; in Item&nbsp;1 of the Form 10-K. Also see Note (P)&nbsp;to the
Condensed Financial Statements herein for information on a letter of intent signed in July&nbsp;2005 to
sell the assets of Southern Company GAS, the natural gas marketing business.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Hurricanes Dennis and Katrina hit Southern Company&#146;s service territory in July and August
2005, respectively. As a result of these storms, as well as Hurricane Ivan in September&nbsp;2004,
Southern Company has incurred significant restoration costs. In addition, fuel costs at each of the
retail operating companies have risen significantly during 2005. Southern Company will continue to
work with its regulators to develop methods to enable the timely recovery of these costs.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Southern Company continues to focus on several key performance indicators. These indicators
include customer satisfaction, peak season equivalent forced outage rate, return on equity, and
earnings per share. For additional information on these indicators, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND
ANALYSIS &#150; OVERVIEW &#150; &#147;Key Performance Indicators&#148; of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Earnings</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Company&#146;s third quarter and year-to-date 2005 earnings were $722&nbsp;million ($0.97
per share) and $1.43&nbsp;billion ($1.92 per share) compared with $644&nbsp;million ($0.87 per share) and
$1.33&nbsp;billion ($1.80 per share), respectively, for the corresponding periods in 2004. Increases in
earnings in the third quarter and year-to-date 2005 primarily resulted from warmer weather in
September&nbsp;2005, sustained economic strength, and customer growth in the Southern Company service
area, as well as a base rate increase at Georgia Power. These increases were partially offset by
the expiration of certain provisions of Georgia Power&#146;s three-year retail rate plan that ended
December&nbsp;31, 2004 (2001 Retail Rate Plan), and higher other operations expenses as compared to the
corresponding periods in 2004. See Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern Company under
&#147;Georgia Power Retail Rate Activity&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information on
Georgia Power&#146;s 2005 rate increase and 2001 Retail Rate Plan.
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">13
</DIV>

</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Retail revenues. </I>The chart below reflects the primary drivers of the 26.0% and 12.7%
increases in retail revenues in the third quarter and year-to-date 2005 when compared to the prior
year. See Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern Company under &#147;Georgia Power Retail Rate
Activity&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information on Georgia Power&#146;s retail base rate increase
that became effective January&nbsp;1, 2005. Changes in revenue related to cost recovery mechanisms such
as fuel, environmental, and storm damage have no effect on net income. In the third quarter and
year-to-date 2005, retail kilowatt-hour energy sales increased by 5.6% and 1.2%, respectively, from
the same periods a year ago, primarily due to warm weather in September&nbsp;2005 and continued customer
and demand growth from sustained economic growth in the Southeast. Even after the effects of
Hurricane Katrina, the number of retail customers increased by 1.1% and weather-adjusted average
consumption by retail customers increased by 1.2% for both the third quarter and year-to-date 2005
when compared with the third quarter and year-to-date 2004. See FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;FERC
and State PSC Matters &#150; Storm Damage Cost Recovery&#148; herein for additional information on the
effects of Hurricane Katrina.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Details of retail revenues are as follows:
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF</DIV>


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Sales for resale</I>. In the third quarter and year-to-date 2005, sales for resale increased
$162.5&nbsp;million, or 47.3%, and $200&nbsp;million, or 19.3%, respectively, over the same periods in 2004.
The increases reflect a rise in fuel revenues due to increases of
39.2% and 20.9%, respectively, in
the average unit cost of fuel per net kilowatt-hour generated when compared to the same periods in
the prior year, and new wholesale contracts between Georgia Power and 30 electric membership
cooperatives (EMCs) and Flint EMC, both beginning in January&nbsp;2005. In addition, Southern Power
entered into new wholesale contracts with Flint EMC in January&nbsp;2005 and added additional wholesale
revenues through its acquisition of Oleander Power Project, L.P. (Oleander) and assumption of
associated PPAs in June&nbsp;2005. See FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Other Matters&#148; herein for
additional information on the Oleander acquisition.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Other electric revenues. </I>In the third quarter and year-to-date 2005, when compared to the
same periods in 2004, other electric revenues increased $11.0&nbsp;million, or 11.0%, and $33.6&nbsp;million,
or 11.7%, respectively. These increases were primarily due to higher transmission revenues of $8.8
million and $18.4&nbsp;million, respectively, and increased outdoor lighting revenues of $1.2&nbsp;million
and $4.4&nbsp;million, respectively, in the third quarter and year-to-date 2005, respectively, as
compared to the same periods in 2004. Customer fees increased $1.5&nbsp;million and $4.1&nbsp;million in the
third quarter and year-to-date 2005, respectively, over the corresponding periods in 2004. Other
electric revenues also increased by $2.8&nbsp;million year-to-date 2005 when compared to the same period
in 2004 as the result of early terminations of customer contracts at Alabama Power and Mississippi
Power.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Fuel expense</I>. Fuel expense was higher in the third quarter and year-to-date 2005 due to
increases of 39.2% and 20.9%, respectively, in the average unit cost of fuel per net kilowatt-hour
generated when compared to the same periods in the prior year. Increases in fuel expense at the
retail operating companies are generally offset by fuel revenues and do not affect net income. See
FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;FERC and State PSC Matters &#150; Fuel Cost Recovery&#148; herein for additional
information. Fuel expenses incurred under Southern Power&#146;s PPAs are generally the responsibility
of the counterparties, and do not significantly affect net income.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Purchased power expense. </I>The $159.6&nbsp;million and $43.6&nbsp;million increases in purchased power
expense in the third quarter and year-to-date 2005, respectively, compared with the same periods in
the prior year are primarily a result of higher fuel prices and higher kilowatt-hour purchases
resulting from increased demand due to warmer weather. Since these expenses generally are offset
by energy revenues, they generally do not have a significant impact on earnings.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Other operations expense. </I>The $106.1&nbsp;million and $132.4&nbsp;million increases in other operations
expense in the third quarter and year-to-date 2005, respectively, compared with the same periods in
the prior year are primarily a result of higher salaries and benefits costs of $62.1&nbsp;million and
$47.1&nbsp;million, respectively. For the third quarter and year-to-date 2005, fossil generation
operations expense increased $12.0&nbsp;million and $22.4&nbsp;million, respectively, and year-to-date
transmission and distribution operations expense increased $48.6&nbsp;million in each case when compared
to the same periods in the prior year. These increases are due to a return to normal spending
levels when compared to the prior year. Also in the third quarter and year-to-date 2005,
insurance and workers compensation expenses increased $21.4&nbsp;million and $12.0&nbsp;million,
respectively, over the corresponding periods in 2004.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Maintenance expense. </I>The $45.4&nbsp;million increase in maintenance expense year-to-date 2005 is
mainly attributable to $45&nbsp;million of expenses recorded by Alabama Power in accordance with an
accounting order approved by the Alabama PSC to offset the costs of Hurricane Ivan and restore the
natural disaster reserve. In accordance with the accounting order, Alabama Power also returned
certain regulatory liabilities related to deferred taxes to its retail customers; therefore, the
combined effects of this accounting order had no impact on net income. See Note 3 to the financial
statements of Southern Company under &#147;Gulf Power and Alabama
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">15
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF</DIV>


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Power Storm Damage Recovery&#148; in Item&nbsp;8
of the Form 10-K and &#147;Income taxes&#148; below for additional information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Depreciation
and amortization expense</I>. The $58.8&nbsp;million and $165.1&nbsp;million increases in
depreciation and amortization in the third quarter and year-to-date 2005, respectively, when
compared to the prior year are primarily due to the expiration in 2004 of certain provisions in
Georgia Power&#146;s 2001 Retail Rate Plan. In accordance with the 2001 Retail Rate Plan, Georgia Power
amortized an accelerated cost recovery liability equally as a credit to amortization expense and
recognized new Georgia PSC-certified purchased power costs in rates evenly over the three years
ended December&nbsp;31, 2004. This treatment resulted in a credit to amortization expense of $47
million and $140&nbsp;million during the third quarter and year-to-date 2004, respectively. See Note 3
to the financial statements of Southern Company under &#147;Georgia Power Retail Rate Activity&#148; in Item
8 of the Form 10-K for additional information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Taxes other than income taxes. </I>The $17.9&nbsp;million and $30.7&nbsp;million increases in taxes other
than income taxes in the third quarter and year-to-date 2005, respectively, compared with the same
periods in the prior year are primarily a result of increases in franchise and gross receipts taxes
associated with increases in revenues from energy sales.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Allowance for equity funds used during construction</I>. The $8.9&nbsp;million increase in AFUDC
equity year-to-date 2005 compared to the same period in the prior year relates primarily to
construction of the McIntosh combined cycle units 10 and 11 by Georgia Power and Savannah Electric.
See Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern Company under &#147;Plant McIntosh Construction
Project&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for further information. AFUDC equity is non-taxable. See
Note (H)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for information on the impact on Southern
Company&#146;s 2005 annual effective tax rate.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Equity in losses of unconsolidated subsidiaries. </I>The $13.0&nbsp;million and $14.9&nbsp;million
increases in equity in losses of unconsolidated subsidiaries in the third quarter and year-to-date
2005, respectively, compared with the same periods in the prior year reflect increased production
at synfuel production facilities that generate operating losses. These partnerships also claim
federal income tax credits that offset these operating losses and make the projects profitable.
See FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Income Tax Matters &#150; Synthetic Fuel Tax Credits&#148; herein for
further information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Interest expense, net of amounts capitalized. </I>The $29.4&nbsp;million and $53.4&nbsp;million increases
in interest expense, net of amounts capitalized, in the third quarter and year-to-date 2005,
respectively, when compared to the same periods in 2004 are mainly attributed to $11.0&nbsp;million and
$24.2&nbsp;million, respectively, associated with issuance of new long-term and short-term debt, and
$11.2&nbsp;million and $18.2&nbsp;million, respectively, resulting from higher interest rates on variable
rate debt. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150;
&#147;Financing Activities&#148; of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K and herein for additional
information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Other income (expense), net. </I>The increases in other income (expense), net of $14.4&nbsp;million
and $30.3&nbsp;million in the third quarter and year-to-date 2005, respectively, when compared to the
same periods in the prior year, are primarily a result of $13.5&nbsp;million in realized gains on gas
hedges at Georgia Power and Savannah Electric, under programs approved by the Georgia PSC. Also
contributing to the year-to-date 2005 increases over the prior year were a $2.4&nbsp;million increase in
gains on the sale of certain investments, and a $4.9&nbsp;million decrease in charitable contributions.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Income taxes. </I>The $40.2&nbsp;million increase in income taxes in the third quarter 2005 when
compared to the prior year is primarily due to taxes associated with higher net income in 2005,
offset by a $18.6&nbsp;million increase
</DIV>

</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF</DIV>


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">in tax benefits received related to higher production at synfuel
production facilities. The $17.3&nbsp;million decrease in year-to-date 2005 income taxes over the prior
year is primarily the result of the impact of the Alabama PSC accounting order discussed under
&#147;Maintenance expense&#148; above and a $27.9&nbsp;million increase in tax benefits received related to higher
production at synfuel production facilities. The year-to-date 2005 decrease over 2004 is
partially offset by higher net income in 2005. Southern Company&#146;s annual effective income tax rate
is expected to be approximately 27% for 2005. See Note 5 to the financial statements of Southern
Company in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note (H)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for
additional information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The results of operations discussed above are not necessarily indicative of Southern Company&#146;s
future earnings potential. The level of Southern Company&#146;s future earnings depends on numerous
factors that affect the opportunities, challenges, and risks of Southern Company&#146;s primary business
of selling electricity. These factors include the retail operating companies&#146; ability to maintain
a stable regulatory environment, to achieve energy sales growth while containing costs, and to
recover costs related to growing demand and increasingly stringent environmental standards.
Another major factor is the profitability of the competitive market-based wholesale generating
business and federal regulatory policy, which may impact Southern Company&#146;s level of participation
in this market. Future earnings for the electricity business in the near term will depend, in
part, upon growth in energy sales, which is subject to a number of factors. These factors include
weather, competition, new energy contracts with neighboring utilities, energy conservation
practiced by customers, the price of electricity, the price elasticity of demand, and the rate of
economic growth in the service area. For additional information relating to these issues, see
BUSINESS &#150; The SOUTHERN System &#150; &#147;Risk Factors&#148; in Item&nbsp;1 and MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS
&#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Environmental Matters</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Compliance costs related to the Clean Air Act and other environmental regulations could affect
earnings if such costs cannot be fully recovered in rates on a timely basis. For additional
information, including information on certain environmental litigation, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION
AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Environmental Matters&#148; of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7
and Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern Company under &#147;Environmental Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8
of the Form 10-K.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>New Source Review Actions</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On June&nbsp;3, 2005, the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Alabama issued its decision
in favor of Alabama Power on two primary legal issues in the case: (1)&nbsp;the scope of the routine
maintenance repair and replacement exclusion under the New Source Review (NSR)&nbsp;rules and (2)&nbsp;the
proper test for calculating emissions increases under those rules. The court decided that routine
maintenance repair and replacement must be defined with reference to what is routine in the
industry as opposed to what is routine at an individual unit and emissions increases must be
measured against the maximum hourly emission rate. The decision does not resolve the case, nor
does it address other legal issues associated with the EPA&#146;s allegations involving Plant Miller
Units 3 and 4. In separate orders, the court dismissed Alabama Power&#146;s motion for summary judgment
on the Plant Miller claims, stayed the entire case, and referred the parties to mediation. Alabama
Power may refile its motion for summary judgment if the mediation proves unsuccessful. At the
request of the mediator, the deadline for completing the mediation has been extended from September
9, 2005 to November&nbsp;30, 2005. The Georgia Power and Savannah Electric case, which is
pending in federal district court in Georgia, remains administratively closed. The ultimate
outcome of these matters cannot now be determined. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS -
FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Environmental
</DIV>
<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">17
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF</DIV>


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Matters &#150; New Source Review Actions&#148; of Southern Company
in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern Company under &#147;Environmental Matters &#150;
New Source Review Actions&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note (B)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial
Statements herein under &#147;New Source Review Actions&#148; for additional information.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On June&nbsp;24, 2005, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit upheld, in
part, the EPA&#146;s December&nbsp;2002 revisions to its NSR regulations, which included changes to the
regulatory exclusions and methods of calculating emissions increases. However, the court vacated
portions of those revisions, including those addressing the exclusion of certain pollution control
projects. On October&nbsp;20, 2005, the EPA published a proposed rule clarifying the test for
determining when an emissions increase is subject to the NSR requirements. The impact of the
proposed rules will depend on adoption of the final rules by the EPA and the individual state
implementation of such rules, as well as the outcome of any additional legal challenges, and,
therefore, cannot be determined at this time.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Plant Wansley Environmental Litigation</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In March&nbsp;2005, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit accepted Georgia Power&#146;s petition
for review of the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Georgia&#146;s December&nbsp;15, 2004
order related to the Plant Wansley environmental litigation. Oral argument is scheduled for early
2006. The ultimate outcome of this matter cannot now be determined. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION
AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Environmental Matters &#150; Plant Wansley Environmental
Litigation&#148; of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern
Company under &#147;Environmental Matters &#150; Plant Wansley Environmental Litigation&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the
Form 10-K and Note (B)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein under &#147;Plant Wansley
Environmental Litigation&#148; for additional information.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Carbon Dioxide Litigation</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Environmental Matters &#150;
Carbon Dioxide Litigation&#148; of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for information on a
complaint filed by attorneys general from eight states, each outside of Southern Company&#146;s service
territory, and the corporation counsel for New York City in July&nbsp;2004 against Southern Company and
four other electric power companies alleging that the companies&#146; emissions of carbon dioxide, a
greenhouse gas, contribute to global warming, which the plaintiffs assert is a public nuisance. A
nearly identical complaint was filed by three environmental groups in the same court. In September
2005, the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York dismissed these cases. The
plaintiffs filed an appeal on October&nbsp;19, 2005. The ultimate outcome of this matter cannot be
determined at this time.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Other Environmental Matters</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The EPA issued the final Clean Air Interstate Rule on March&nbsp;10, 2005. The rule addresses sulfur
dioxide (SO<SUB>2</SUB>) and nitrogen oxide (NO<SUB>x</SUB>) emissions that contribute to
nonattainment of the eight-hour ozone and fine particulate matter National Ambient Air Quality
Standards. Twenty-eight eastern states, including each of the
states within Southern Company&#146;s service area, are subject to the fine particulate matter and/or
the eight-hour ozone requirements set forth within the rule. The rule may require additional
reductions of NO<SUB>x</SUB> and/or SO<SUB>2</SUB> to be achieved by the installation of additional
controls at Southern Company&#146;s coal-fired facilities or through the purchase of allowances.
</DIV>



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">18
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">
<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF</DIV>


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</DIV>




<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On March&nbsp;15, 2005, the EPA announced the final Clean Air Mercury Rule, selecting a
cap-and-trade approach to be implemented in two phases, 2010 and 2018. The rule sets a permanent
cap on emissions at the 2018 level and provides for an emissions allowance trading market.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On June&nbsp;15, 2005, the EPA issued final rules addressing Best Available Retrofit Technology
(BART)&nbsp;standards under the Regional Haze Program. States must develop regulations to implement the
federal regional haze requirements, including BART standards, by December&nbsp;17, 2007.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On June&nbsp;14 and 15, 2005, the EPA published final rules approving the redesignation of the
Atlanta metro area to &#147;attainment&#148; under the one-hour ground-level ozone standard. On June&nbsp;15,
2005, the EPA revoked the one-hour ground-level ozone standard, in connection with the
implementation of its new eight-hour ozone standard.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On September&nbsp;8, 2005, the EPA proposed a rule for the implementation of the fine particulate
matter air quality standard. Several areas within Southern Company&#146;s service area in Alabama and
Georgia were previously designated by the EPA as &#147;nonattainment&#148; for the standard. The EPA plans
to finalize the proposed implementation rule in 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The impact of these rules on Southern Company will depend on the outcome of legal challenges
and development and implementation of applicable state regulations and therefore cannot be
determined at this time.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>FERC and State PSC Matters</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Market-Based Rate Authority</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"> </FONT>&#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;FERC and State
PSC Matters &#150; Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the
financial statements of Southern Company under &#147;Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the
Form 10-K for information on the FERC&#146;s April&nbsp;2004 order adopting a new interim analysis for
measuring generation market power and a proceeding initiated by the FERC in December&nbsp;2004 to
assess Southern Company&#146;s generation dominance within its retail service territory. Each of the
retail operating companies and Southern Power has authorization from the FERC to sell power to
non-affiliates at market-based prices. Through SCS, as agent, the retail operating companies
and Southern Power also have FERC authority to make short-term opportunity sales at market
rates. Specific FERC approval must be obtained with respect to a market-based contract with an
affiliate. On February&nbsp;15, 2005, Southern Company submitted additional information related to
generation dominance in Southern Company&#146;s retail service territory. A hearing before an
administrative law judge to review the February filing is scheduled for March&nbsp;2006. Any new
market-based rate transactions in its retail service territory entered into after February&nbsp;27,
2005 will be subject to refund to the level of the default cost-based rates, pending the outcome
of the proceeding. In the event that the FERC&#146;s default mitigation measures are ultimately
applied, the retail operating companies and Southern Power may be required to charge cost-based
rates for certain wholesale sales in the Southern Company retail service territory, which may be
lower than negotiated market-based rates. The impact of such sales through September&nbsp;30, 2005
is not material to Southern Company&#146;s net income. The final outcome of this matter will depend
on the form in which the final methodology for assessing generation market power and mitigation
rules may be ultimately adopted and cannot be determined at this time.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition, in May&nbsp;2005, the FERC started an investigation to determine whether Southern
Company satisfies the other three parts of the FERC&#146;s market-based rate analysis: transmission
market power, barriers to entry, and affiliate abuse or reciprocal dealing. The FERC established a
new refund period related to this expanded investigation. Any and all new market-based rate
transactions involving any Southern Company
</DIV>

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Intercompany Interchange Contract</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Also, in May&nbsp;2005, the FERC initiated a new proceeding to examine (1)&nbsp;the provisions of the IIC
among Alabama Power, Georgia Power, Gulf Power, Mississippi Power, Savannah Electric, Southern
Power, and SCS, as agent, under the terms of which the power pool of Southern Company is operated,
and, in particular, the propriety of the continued inclusion of Southern Power as a party to the
IIC, (2)&nbsp;whether any parties to the IIC have violated the FERC&#146;s standards of conduct applicable to
utility companies that are transmission providers, and (3)&nbsp;whether Southern Company&#146;s code of
conduct defining Southern Power as a &#147;system company&#148; rather than a &#147;marketing affiliate&#148; is just
and reasonable. In connection with the formation of Southern Power, the FERC authorized Southern
Power&#146;s inclusion in the IIC in 2000. The FERC also previously approved Southern Company&#146;s code of
conduct. The FERC order directs that the administrative law judge who presided over the McIntosh
PPA proceeding be assigned to preside over the hearing in this proceeding and that the testimony
and exhibits presented in that proceeding be preserved to the extent appropriate. The hearing is
scheduled for June&nbsp;2006. See Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern Company under &#147;Plant
McIntosh Construction Project&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for further information on the McIntosh
PPA proceeding. Effective July&nbsp;19, 2005, revenues from transactions under the IIC involving any
Southern Company subsidiaries will be subject to refund to the extent the FERC orders any changes
to the IIC.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Southern Company and its subsidiaries believe that there is no meritorious basis for these
allegations and intend to vigorously defend themselves in the proceeding. However, the final
outcome of this matter, including any remedies to be applied in the event of an adverse ruling in
this proceeding, cannot now be determined.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Generation Interconnection Agreements</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;FERC and State PSC Matters
&#150; Generation Interconnection Agreements&#148; of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for
information on the FERC&#146;s Order 2003 related to standardization of generation interconnection
agreements and procedures. The FERC has indicated that Order 2003, which was effective January&nbsp;20,
2004, is to be applied prospectively to interconnection agreements. Subsidiaries of Tenaska, Inc.,
as counterparties to three previously executed interconnection agreements with subsidiaries of
Southern Company, have filed complaints at the FERC requesting that the FERC modify the agreements
and that Southern Company refund a total of $19&nbsp;million previously paid for interconnection
facilities, with interest. Southern Company has also received similar requests from other entities
totaling approximately $14&nbsp;million. Southern Company has opposed such relief, and the proceedings
are still pending. The impact of Order 2003 and its subsequent rehearings on Southern Company and
the final results of these matters cannot be determined at this time.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Alabama Power Environmental Rate Filing</I>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On October&nbsp;5, 2004, the Alabama PSC approved a specific rate mechanism for the recovery of
Alabama Power&#146;s retail costs associated with environmental laws, regulations, or other such
mandates. The rate mechanism began operation in January&nbsp;2005 and provides for the recovery of
these costs pursuant to a factor
</DIV>
<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">20
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">
<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B>

recovered include operation and maintenance expenses, depreciation, and a return on invested
capital. Retail rates increased 1% in January&nbsp;2005, which should yield an annual recovery of
approximately $33&nbsp;million, and are expected to increase approximately 1% in 2006. In

any retail rate increase under its previously approved Rate Stabilization and Equalization Plan
(Rate RSE). See &#147;Alabama Power Base Rates&#148; below for further information on Rate RSE.

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Alabama Power Rate RSE</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern Company under &#147;Alabama Power Retail
Regulatory Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information on Alabama Power&#146;s Rate RSE. On
October&nbsp;4, 2005, the Alabama PSC approved a revision to Rate RSE requested by Alabama Power.
Rate RSE adjustments can be made effective January&nbsp;2007 and annually thereafter and will be
based on forward-looking information for the
applicable upcoming calendar year. Rate adjustments for any two-year period, when averaged
together, cannot exceed 4% per year and any annual adjustment is limited to 5%. The range of
return on common equity, on which such adjustments are based, remains unchanged. If Alabama
Power&#146;s actual retail return on common equity is above the allowed equity return range, customer
refunds will be required; however, there is no provision for additional customer billings should
the actual retail return on common equity fall below the allowed equity return range. Alabama
Power will make its initial submission of projected data for calendar year 2007 by December&nbsp;1,
2006.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Retail Fuel Cost Recovery</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The retail operating companies each have established fuel cost recovery rates approved by their
respective state PSCs. In recent quarters, the retail operating companies have experienced higher
than expected fuel costs for coal and gas. These higher fuel costs have increased the under
recovered fuel costs included in the balance sheets to approximately $985&nbsp;million at September&nbsp;30,
2005. Operating revenues are adjusted for differences in actual recoverable fuel costs and amounts
billed in current regulated rates. Accordingly, changes to the billing factors will have no
significant effect on Southern Company&#146;s revenues or net income, but will affect annual cash flow.
The retail operating companies will continue to monitor the under recovered fuel cost balance in
light of these higher fuel costs.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On October&nbsp;19, 2005, Alabama Power filed with the Alabama PSC for a fuel cost recovery
increase under the provisions of its energy cost recovery rate (Rate ECR). An approval of this
filing would result in an increase of the energy billing factor for retail customers from 1.788
cents per kilowatt-hour to 2.650 cents per kilowatt-hour and would become effective December&nbsp;3,
2005. This change represents an $8.62 per month increase for an average residential customer
billing of 1,000 kilowatt-hours. The requested increase is intended to allow for the recovery of
energy costs based on an estimate of future energy costs, as well as the collection of the existing
under recovered energy costs by the end of 2006. Alabama Power&#146;s under recovered retail energy
costs as of September&nbsp;30, 2005 totaled $182.4&nbsp;million. Under the terms of Rate ECR, the increase
will be effective 45&nbsp;days after the filing unless modified by the Alabama PSC following a public
hearing. The final outcome of this filing cannot be determined at this time. See Note 3 to the
financial statements of Southern Company under &#147;Alabama Power Retail Regulatory Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8
of the Form 10-K and Note (I)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for additional
information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On May&nbsp;17, 2005, the Georgia PSC voted to allow Georgia Power to increase customer fuel rates
to recover estimated under-recovered fuel costs of approximately $508&nbsp;million as of May&nbsp;31, 2005
over the period from June&nbsp;1, 2005 through May&nbsp;31, 2009, as well as future projected fuel costs
based on a June&nbsp;2005 through May&nbsp;2006 test period. The new fuel rate became effective June&nbsp;1, 2005
and represents an average annual increase in customer billings of approximately 9.5%, or
approximately $473&nbsp;million. Based on the order, a portion of the under recovered regulatory clause
revenues was reclassified from current assets to deferred charges and other assets
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">21
</DIV>
