</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">issues, see BUSINESS &#151; The SOUTHERN System &#151; &#147;Risk Factors&#148; in Item&nbsp;1 and MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION
AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL of Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Environmental Matters</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Compliance costs related to the Clean Air Act and other environmental regulations could affect
earnings if such costs cannot be fully recovered in rates on a timely basis. For additional
information, including information on certain environmental litigation, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION
AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#151; &#147;Environmental Matters&#148; of Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;7 and
Note 3 to the financial statements of Alabama Power under &#147;Environmental Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the
Form 10-K.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>New Source Review Actions</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On June&nbsp;3, 2005, the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Alabama issued its decision
in favor of Alabama Power on two primary legal issues in the case: (1)&nbsp;the scope of the routine
maintenance repair and replacement exclusion under the New Source Review (NSR)&nbsp;rules and (2)&nbsp;the
proper test for calculating emissions increases under those rules. The court decided that routine
maintenance repair and replacement must be defined with reference to what is routine in the
industry as opposed to what is routine at an individual unit and emissions increases must be
measured against the maximum hourly emission rate. The decision does not resolve the case, nor
does it address other legal issues associated with the EPA&#146;s allegations involving Plant Miller
Units 3 and 4. In separate orders, the court dismissed Alabama Power&#146;s motion for summary judgment
on the Plant Miller claims, stayed the entire case, and referred the parties to mediation. Alabama
Power may refile its motion for summary judgment if the mediation proves unsuccessful. At the
request of the mediator, the original deadline for completing the mediation has been extended from
September&nbsp;9, 2005 to November&nbsp;30, 2005. The ultimate outcome of this matter cannot now be
determined. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#151; &#147;Environmental
Matters &#151; New Source Review Actions&#148; of Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial
statements of Alabama Power under &#147;New Source Review Actions&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note
(B)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein under &#147;New Source Review Actions&#148; for additional
information.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On June&nbsp;24, 2005, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit upheld, in
part, the EPA&#146;s December&nbsp;2002 revisions to its NSR regulations, which included changes to the
regulatory exclusions and methods of calculating emissions increases. However, the court vacated
portions of those revisions, including those addressing the exclusion of certain pollution control
projects. On October&nbsp;20, 2005, the EPA published a proposed rule clarifying the test for
determining when an emissions increase is subject to the NSR requirements. The impact of the
proposed rules will depend on adoption of the final rules by the EPA and the individual state
implementation of such rules, as well as the outcome of any additional legal challenges, and,
therefore, cannot be determined at this time.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Carbon Dioxide Litigation</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#151; &#147;Environmental Matters &#151;
Carbon Dioxide Litigation&#148; of Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for information on a
complaint filed by attorneys general from eight states, each outside of Southern Company&#146;s service
territory, and the corporation counsel for New York City in July&nbsp;2004 against Southern Company and
four other electric power companies alleging that the companies&#146; emissions of carbon dioxide, a
greenhouse gas, contribute to global warming, which the plaintiffs assert is a public nuisance. A
nearly identical complaint
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">40
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>ALABAMA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">was filed by three environmental groups in the same court. In September&nbsp;2005, the U.S. District
Court for the Southern District of New York dismissed these cases. The plaintiffs filed an appeal
on October&nbsp;19, 2005. The ultimate outcome of this matter cannot be determined at this time.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Other Environmental Matters</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The EPA issued the final Clean Air Interstate Rule on March&nbsp;10, 2005. The rule addresses sulfur
dioxide (SO<SUB>2</SUB>) and nitrogen oxide (NO<SUB>x</SUB>) emissions that contribute to
nonattainment of the eight-hour ozone and fine particulate matter National Ambient Air Quality
Standards. Twenty-eight eastern states, including the State of Alabama, are subject to the fine
particulate matter and/or the eight-hour ozone requirements set forth within the rule. The rule
may require additional reductions of NO<SUB>x</SUB> and/or SO<SUB>2</SUB> to be achieved by the
installation of additional controls at Alabama Power&#146;s coal-fired facilities or through the
purchase of allowances.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On March&nbsp;15, 2005, the EPA announced the final Clean Air Mercury Rule, selecting a
cap-and-trade approach to be implemented in two phases, 2010 and 2018. The rule sets a permanent
cap on emissions at the

2018 level and provides for an emissions allowance trading market.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On June&nbsp;15, 2005, the EPA issued final rules addressing Best Available Retrofit Technology
(BART)&nbsp;standards under the Regional Haze Program. States must develop regulations to implement the
federal regional haze requirements, including BART standards, by December&nbsp;17, 2007.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On September&nbsp;8, 2005, the EPA proposed a rule for the implementation of the fine particulate
matter air quality standard. Several areas within Alabama Power&#146;s service area were previously
designated by the EPA as &#147;nonattainment&#148; for the standard. The EPA plans to finalize the proposed
implementation rule in 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The impact of these rules on Alabama Power will depend on the outcome of legal challenges and
development and implementation of applicable state regulations and therefore cannot be determined
at this time.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>FERC and Alabama PSC Matters</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Market-Based Rate Authority</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"> </FONT>&#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#151; &#147;FERC and
Alabama PSC Matters &#151; Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; of Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the
financial statements of Alabama Power under &#147;Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form
10-K for information on the FERC&#146;s April&nbsp;2004 order adopting a new interim analysis for
measuring generation market power and a proceeding initiated by the FERC in December&nbsp;2004 to
assess Southern Company&#146;s generation dominance within its retail service territory. Alabama
Power has authorization from the FERC to sell power to non-affiliates at market-based prices.
Alabama Power, through SCS as agent, also has FERC authority to make short-term opportunity
sales at market rates. Specific FERC approval must be obtained with respect to a market-based
contract with an affiliate. On February&nbsp;15, 2005, Southern Company submitted additional
information related to generation dominance in its retail service territory. A hearing before
an administrative law judge to review the February filing is scheduled for March&nbsp;2006. Any new
market-based rate transactions in Southern Company&#146;s retail service territory entered into after
February&nbsp;27, 2005 will be subject to refund to the level of the default cost-based rates,
pending the outcome of the proceeding. In the event that the FERC&#146;s default mitigation measures
are ultimately applied, Alabama Power may be required to charge cost-based rates for certain
wholesale sales in the Southern Company retail service territory, which may be lower than
negotiated market-based rates. The impact of such sales through September&nbsp;30, 2005 is not
material to Alabama Power&#146;s net income. The final outcome of this matter will
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">41
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>ALABAMA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">depend on the form in which the final methodology for assessing generation market power and
mitigation rules may be ultimately adopted and cannot be determined at this time.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition, in May&nbsp;2005, the FERC started an investigation to determine whether Southern
Company satisfies the other three parts of the FERC&#146;s market-based rate analysis: transmission
market power, barriers to entry, and affiliate abuse or reciprocal dealing. The FERC established a
new refund period related to this expanded investigation. Any and all new market-based rate
transactions involving any Southern Company subsidiary will be subject to refund to the extent the
FERC orders lower rates as a result of this new investigation, with the refund period beginning
July&nbsp;19, 2005. The FERC also directed that this expanded proceeding be held in abeyance pending
the outcome of the proceeding on the IIC discussed below. The impact of such sales through
September&nbsp;30, 2005 is not material to Alabama Power&#146;s net income.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Southern Company and its subsidiaries believe that there is no meritorious basis for these
allegations and intend to vigorously defend themselves in the proceeding. However, the final
outcome of this matter, including any remedies to be applied in the event of an adverse ruling in
this proceeding, cannot now be determined.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Intercompany Interchange Contract</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Also, in May&nbsp;2005, the FERC initiated a new proceeding to examine (1)&nbsp;the provisions of the IIC
among Alabama Power, Georgia Power, Gulf Power, Mississippi Power, Savannah Electric, Southern
Power, and SCS, as agent, under the terms of which the power pool of Southern Company is operated,
and, in particular, the propriety of the continued inclusion of Southern Power as a party to the
IIC, (2)&nbsp;whether any parties to the IIC have violated the FERC&#146;s standards of conduct applicable to
utility companies that are transmission providers, and (3)&nbsp;whether Southern Company&#146;s code of
conduct defining Southern Power as a &#147;system company&#148; rather than a &#147;marketing affiliate&#148; is just
and reasonable. In connection with the formation of Southern Power, the FERC authorized Southern
Power&#146;s inclusion in the IIC in 2000. The FERC also previously approved Southern Company&#146;s code of
conduct. The FERC order directs that the administrative law judge who presided over a previous
proceeding involving Southern Power, Georgia Power and Savannah Electric be assigned to preside
over the hearing in this proceeding and that the testimony and exhibits presented in that
proceeding be preserved to the extent appropriate. The hearing is scheduled for June&nbsp;2006.
Effective July&nbsp;19, 2005, revenues from transactions under the IIC involving any Southern Company
subsidiaries will be subject to refund to the extent the FERC orders any changes to the IIC.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Southern Company and its subsidiaries believe that there is no meritorious basis for these
allegations and intend to vigorously defend themselves in the proceeding. However, the final
outcome of this matter, including any remedies to be applied in the event of an adverse ruling in
this proceeding, cannot now be determined.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Generation Interconnection Agreements</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#151; &#147;FERC and Alabama PSC
Matters &#151; Generation Interconnection Agreements&#148; of Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for
information on the FERC&#146;s Order 2003 related to standardization of generation interconnection
agreements and procedures. The FERC has indicated that Order 2003, which was effective January&nbsp;20,
2004, is to be applied prospectively to interconnection agreements. Subsidiaries of Tenaska, Inc.,
as counterparties to two previously executed interconnection agreements with Alabama Power, have
filed complaints at the FERC requesting that the FERC modify the agreements and that Alabama Power
refund a total of $11&nbsp;million previously paid for interconnection facilities, with interest.
Alabama Power has also received similar requests from other entities totaling $7&nbsp;million. Alabama
Power has opposed such relief, and the proceedings are still

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">42
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

</DIV>


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>ALABAMA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">pending. The impact of Order 2003 and its subsequent rehearings on Alabama Power and the final
results of these matters cannot be determined at this time.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Environmental Rate Filing</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On October&nbsp;5, 2004, the Alabama PSC approved a specific rate mechanism for the recovery of
Alabama Power&#146;s retail costs associated with environmental laws, regulations, or other such
mandates. The rate mechanism began operation in January&nbsp;2005 and provides for the recovery of
these costs pursuant to a factor that will be calculated annually. Environmental costs to be
recovered include operation and maintenance<BR>
expenses, depreciation, and a return on invested capital. Retail rates increased 1% in January
2005, which should yield an annual recovery of approximately $33&nbsp;million, and are expected to
increase approximately 1% in 2006. In conjunction with the Alabama PSC&#146;s approval, Alabama
Power agreed to a moratorium until 2007 on any retail rate increase under its previously
approved Rate Stabilization and Equalization Plan (Rate RSE). See &#147;Rate RSE&#148; below for further
information.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Rate RSE</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See Note 3 to the financial statements of Alabama Power under &#147;Retail Regulatory Matters&#148; in
Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information on Alabama Power&#146;s Rate RSE. On October&nbsp;4, 2005, the
Alabama PSC approved a revision to Rate RSE requested by Alabama Power. Rate RSE adjustments
can be made effective January&nbsp;2007 and annually thereafter and will be based on forward-looking
information for the applicable upcoming calendar year. Rate adjustments for any two-year
period, when averaged together, cannot exceed 4% per year and any annual adjustment is limited
to 5%. The range of return on common equity, on which such adjustments are based, remains
unchanged. If Alabama Power&#146;s actual retail return on common equity is above the allowed equity
return range, customer refunds will be required; however, there is no provision for additional
customer billings should the actual retail return on common equity fall below the allowed equity
return range. Alabama Power will make its initial submission of projected data for calendar
year 2007 by December&nbsp;1, 2006.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Hydro Relicensing</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On July&nbsp;28, 2005, Alabama Power filed two applications with the FERC for a new 50-year license for
Alabama Power&#146;s seven hydroelectric developments on the Coosa River (Weiss, Henry, Logan Martin,
Lay, Mitchell, Jordan, and Bouldin) and a new 50-year license for the Lewis Smith and Bankhead
developments on the Warrior River. The FERC licenses for all of these nine projects expire in
2007. Upon or after the expiration of each license, the United States Government, by act of
Congress, may take over the project or the FERC may relicense the project either to the original
licensee or to a new licensee. The FERC may grant relicenses subject to certain requirements that
could result in additional costs to Alabama Power. The final outcome of this matter cannot be
determined at this time. See Note (I)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for additional
information.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Nuclear Relicensing</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#151; &#147;FERC and Alabama PSC
Matters &#151; Nuclear Relicensing&#148; of Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 1 to the financial statements
of Alabama Power under &#147;Nuclear Decommissioning&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information on
Alabama Power&#146;s application to extend the operating license for Plant Farley for an additional 20
years and Alabama Power&#146;s nuclear decommissioning trust funds (NDT). In May&nbsp;2005, the NRC approved
the license extension. Consequently, amounts previously contributed to the NDT are currently
projected to be adequate to meet the decommissioning obligations. Therefore, in June&nbsp;2005, the
Alabama PSC approved a request by Alabama Power to suspend, effective January&nbsp;1, 2005, the
inclusion in its annual cost of service of $18&nbsp;million

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">43
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

</DIV>


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>ALABAMA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">in decommissioning costs and to suspend also the associated obligation to make semi-annual
contributions to the NDT. Should projections of balances in the external trusts prove to be
inadequate to meet future estimates for decommissioning costs, Alabama Power would seek Alabama PSC
approval to address that issue in a manner consistent with NRC and other applicable requirements.
See Note (I)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for additional information.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Retail Fuel Cost Recovery</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On October&nbsp;19, 2005, Alabama Power filed with the Alabama PSC for a fuel cost recovery increase
under the provisions of its energy cost recovery rate (Rate ECR). An approval of this filing would
result in an increase of the energy billing factor for retail customers from 1.788 cents per
kilowatt-hour to 2.650 cents per kilowatt-hour and would become effective December&nbsp;3, 2005. This
change to the billing factor represents on average an increase of approximately $8.62 per month for
a customer billing of 1,000 kilowatt-hours. Rate ECR revenues as recorded on the financial
statements are adjusted for differences in actual recoverable costs and amounts billed in current
regulated rates. Accordingly, this increase in the billing factor will have no significant effect
on Alabama Power&#146;s revenues or net income, but will increase annual cash flow. The requested
increase is intended to allow for the recovery of energy costs based on an estimate of future
energy costs, as well as the collection of the existing under recovered energy costs by the end of
2006. Alabama Power&#146;s under recovered retail energy costs as of September&nbsp;30, 2005 totaled $182.4
million. Under the terms of Rate ECR, the increase will be effective 45&nbsp;days after the filing
unless modified by the Alabama PSC following a public hearing. The final outcome of this filing
cannot be determined at this time. See Note (I)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for
additional information.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Natural Disaster Cost Recovery</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#151; &#147;FERC and Alabama PSC
Matters &#151; Natural Disaster Cost Recovery&#148; of Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Notes 1 and 3 to the
financial statements of Alabama Power under &#147;Natural Disaster Reserve&#148; and &#147;Natural Disaster Cost
Recovery,&#148; respectively, in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. Alabama Power maintains a reserve for
property damage to cover the cost of damages from major storms to its transmission and distribution
lines and the cost of uninsured damages to its generation facilities and other property.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On July&nbsp;10, 2005 and August&nbsp;29, 2005, Hurricanes Dennis and Katrina, respectively, impacted
the coast of Alabama and continued north through the state of Alabama, causing significant damage
in parts of the service territory of Alabama Power. Approximately 241,000 and 637,000,
respectively, of Alabama Power&#146;s 1.4&nbsp;million customer accounts were without electrical service
immediately after Hurricanes Dennis and Katrina. Alabama Power sustained significant damage to its
distribution and transmission facilities during these storms.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In August&nbsp;2005, Alabama Power received approval from the Alabama PSC to defer the Hurricane
Dennis storm-related operation and maintenance costs (estimated at $28&nbsp;million), which resulted in
a negative balance in the natural disaster reserve. In October&nbsp;2005, Alabama Power also received
similar approval from the Alabama PSC to defer the Hurricane Katrina storm-related operation and
maintenance costs (estimated at $45&nbsp;million). See Note (I)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements
herein for further information concerning the Alabama PSC&#146;s approval of deferring the costs of the
storms. Alabama Power&#146;s current annual accrual to the natural disaster reserve, as approved by the
Alabama PSC, is $3&nbsp;million, with additional accruals allowed whenever the reserve balance is less
than $22.4&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On November&nbsp;1, 2005, Alabama Power filed a request with the Alabama PSC to approve a plan
designed to recover its deferred Hurricanes Dennis- and Katrina-related operation and maintenance
costs and to replenish
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">44
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>ALABAMA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">its depleted natural disaster reserve. This request would provide for a separate rate rider, Rate
NDR (Natural Disaster Reserve), based on a monthly charge per customer account. Rate NDR would
consist of two components. One part of Rate NDR would be a monthly charge to allow recovery of the
previously deferred storm costs, which totaled approximately $69&nbsp;million as of September&nbsp;30, 2005,
over a two-year period. The second part of Rate NDR would be a monthly charge to replenish the
natural disaster reserve&#146;s balance over a five-year period to a newly authorized target of $75
million. As revenue from Rate NDR is recognized, an equal amount of operation and maintenance
expense related to the natural disaster reserve will also be recognized. As a result, this
increase in revenue and expense will not have an impact on net income, but will increase the annual
cash flow. If approved by the Alabama PSC, Rate NDR would become effective in January, 2006. A
final decision from the Alabama PSC is expected in December&nbsp;2005. The final outcome of the filing
cannot be determined at this time.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Other Matters</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In July&nbsp;2005, the U.S. Congress passed the Energy Policy Act of 2005 (Energy Act), which President
Bush signed into law in August&nbsp;2005. Among other things, the Energy Act includes various tax
subsidies for electric utilities and provisions repealing the PUHCA. The Energy Act also amends
federal energy laws and provides the FERC with new oversight responsibilities for the electric
utility industry. The implementation of the Energy Act requires proceedings at the state level and
the development of regulations by the FERC, as well as other federal agencies. Alabama Power is
still reviewing the legislation. Its impacts will depend on the promulgation and implementation of
final rules and cannot be determined at this time.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Alabama Power is subject to certain claims and legal actions arising in the ordinary course of
business. In addition, Alabama Power&#146;s business activities are subject to extensive governmental
regulation related to public health and the environment. Litigation over environmental issues and
claims of various types, including property damage, personal injury, and citizen enforcement of
environmental requirements, has increased generally throughout the United States. In particular,
personal injury claims for damages caused by alleged exposure to hazardous materials have become
more frequent. The ultimate outcome of such litigation against Alabama Power cannot be predicted
at this time; however, management does not anticipate that the liabilities, if any, arising from
such current proceedings would have a material adverse effect on Alabama Power&#146;s financial
statements.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See the Notes to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for discussion of various other
contingencies, regulatory matters, and other matters being litigated which may affect future
earnings potential.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>ACCOUNTING POLICIES</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Alabama Power prepares its financial statements in accordance with accounting principles generally
accepted in the United States. Significant accounting policies are described in Note 1 to the
financial statements of Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. In the application of these
policies, certain estimates are made that may have a material impact on Alabama Power&#146;s results of
operations and related disclosures. Different assumptions and measurements could produce estimates
that are significantly different from those recorded in the financial statements. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"> &#151; </FONT>ACCOUNTING POLICIES &#151; &#147;Application of Critical Accounting
Policies and Estimates&#148; of Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a complete discussion of
Alabama Power&#146;s critical accounting policies and estimates related to Electric Utility Regulation,
Contingent Obligations, and Unbilled Revenues.
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">45
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>New Accounting Standards</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">FASB Statement No.&nbsp;123R, Share-Based Payments, was issued in December&nbsp;2004. This statement
requires that compensation cost relating to share-based payment transactions be recognized in
financial statements. That cost will be measured based on the grant date fair value of the equity
instruments issued. In April
2005, the SEC amended the compliance dates for FASB Statement No.&nbsp;123R. For Alabama Power, this
statement is now effective beginning January&nbsp;1, 2006. Although the compensation expense
calculation required under the revised statement differs slightly, the impacts on Alabama Power&#146;s
financial statements are expected to be similar to the pro forma disclosures included in Note 1 to
the financial statements of Alabama Power under &#147;Stock Options&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and in
Note (C)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;47 (FIN 47), Accounting for Conditional Asset Retirement Obligations,
was issued in March&nbsp;2005. This interpretation of FASB Statement No.&nbsp;143, Accounting for Asset
Retirement Obligations (FAS No.&nbsp;143), requires that asset retirement obligations be recorded when a
legal obligation exists even though the timing and/or the method of settlement are conditional on a
future event. As required under FAS No.&nbsp;143, the present value of the ultimate cost of retiring
long-lived assets is recorded in the period in which the liability is incurred. The costs are
capitalized as part of the related long-lived asset and depreciated over the asset&#146;s useful life.
For Alabama Power, FIN 47 is effective no later than December&nbsp;31, 2005. Alabama Power currently
expects to record additional asset retirement obligations (and plant in service) of less than $47
million, primarily related to asbestos removal and disposal of polychlorinated biphenyls in certain
transformers. However, Alabama Power has not concluded its assessment of FIN 47 and other
potential obligations are still being evaluated. The adoption of FIN 47 is not expected to have
any effect on Alabama Power&#146;s income statement.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In December&nbsp;2004, the FASB issued Staff Position No.&nbsp;109-1 (FSP 109-1), Application of FASB
Statement No.&nbsp;109, Accounting for Income Taxes, to the Tax Deduction on Qualified Production
Activities provided by the American Jobs Creation Act of 2004, which requires that the generation
deduction for utilities be accounted for as a special tax deduction rather than as a tax rate
reduction. Alabama Power adopted FSP 109-1 in the first quarter of 2005 with no material impact on
its financial statements.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Overview</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Alabama Power&#146;s financial condition continued to be stable at September&nbsp;30, 2005. Net cash flows
from operating activities totaled $718.2&nbsp;million for the first nine months of 2005, compared to
$745.1&nbsp;million for the first nine months of 2004. The $26.9&nbsp;million decrease in the first nine
months resulted primarily from higher fuel costs. Those costs are recoverable in future periods
and are reflected on the balance sheets as under recovered regulatory clause revenues. Gross
property additions to utility plant were $605.7&nbsp;million in the first nine months of 2005 and are
included in the balance sheets herein. The majority of funds needed for gross property additions
since 2000 has been provided from operating activities.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS -
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"> &#151; </FONT> &#147;Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations&#148; of
Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a description of Alabama Power&#146;s capital requirements
for its construction program, scheduled maturities of
 </DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">46
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">



<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>ALABAMA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">long-term debt, as well as related interest, preferred stock dividends, lease obligations, purchase
commitments, and trust funding requirements. See Note (I)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements
herein for information concerning the suspension of the funding of the Nuclear Decommissioning
Trust. Approximately $422&nbsp;million will be required by September&nbsp;30, 2006 for redemptions and
maturities of long-term debt.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Sources of Capital</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Alabama Power plans to obtain the funds required for construction and other
purposes from sources similar to those used in the past, including funds from operations and new
security issuances. The amount, type, and timing of any financings &#151; if needed &#151; will depend
upon maintenance of adequate earnings, regulatory approval, prevailing market conditions, and other
factors. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#151; &#147;Sources
of Capital&#148; of Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for additional information.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;To meet short-term cash needs and contingencies, Alabama Power had at September&nbsp;30, 2005
approximately $146&nbsp;million of cash and cash equivalents, unused committed lines of credit of
approximately $873&nbsp;million (including $504&nbsp;million of such lines which are dedicated to funding
purchase obligations relating to variable rate pollution control bonds), of which $0.5&nbsp;million will
expire at various times during the remainder of 2005, and an extendible commercial note program.
Alabama Power expects to renew its credit facilities, as needed, prior to expiration. See Note 6
to the financial statements of Alabama Power under &#147;Bank Credit Arrangements&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form
10-K for additional information. Alabama Power may also meet short-term cash needs through a
Southern Company subsidiary organized to issue and sell commercial paper and extendible commercial
notes at the request and for the benefit of Alabama Power and other Southern Company subsidiaries.
Alabama Power has regulatory authority for up to $1.4&nbsp;billion of short-term borrowings. At
September&nbsp;30, 2005, Alabama Power had no commercial paper or extendible notes payable outstanding.
Management believes that the need for working capital can be adequately met by issuing commercial
paper or utilizing lines of credit without maintaining large cash balances.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Credit Rating Risk</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Alabama Power does not have any credit arrangements that would require material changes in payment
schedules or terminations as a result of a credit rating downgrade. However, Alabama Power is
party to certain derivative agreements that could require collateral and/or accelerated payment in
the event of a credit rating change to below investment grade. These agreements are primarily for
natural gas price risk management activities. At September&nbsp;30, 2005, Alabama Power had no material
exposure related to these agreements.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Market Price Risk</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Alabama Power&#146;s market risk exposures relative to interest rate changes have not changed materially
compared with the December&nbsp;31, 2004 reporting period. In addition, Alabama Power is not aware of
any facts or circumstances that would significantly affect such exposures in the near term.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Due to cost-based rate regulations, Alabama Power has limited exposure to market volatility in
interest rates, commodity fuel prices, and prices of electricity. To mitigate residual risks
relative to movements in electricity prices, Alabama Power enters into fixed-price contracts for
the purchase and sale of electricity through the wholesale electricity market. Alabama Power has
also implemented a retail fuel hedging program at the instruction of the Alabama PSC.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">47
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For additional information, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FINANCIAL CONDITION
AND LIQUIDITY<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"> &#151;</FONT> &#147;Market Price Risk&#148; of Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Notes 1 and 6 to the
financial statements of Alabama Power under &#147;Financial Instruments&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and
Note (F)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Financing Activities</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the first quarter 2005, Alabama Power issued $250&nbsp;million of Series&nbsp;DD 5.65% Senior Notes due
March&nbsp;15, 2035. The proceeds from the sale were used to repay a portion of Alabama Power&#146;s
outstanding short-term indebtedness and for other general corporate purposes, including Alabama
Power&#146;s continuing construction activities. Alabama Power settled interest rate swaps related to
the transaction at a cost of $21&nbsp;million, which was recorded in other comprehensive income. This
cost will be amortized over a 30-year period.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the second quarter 2005, Alabama Power entered into two interest rate hedges related to the
anticipated issuance of senior notes totaling $600&nbsp;million. The notes are expected to be issued in
2005 and 2006. Also, in the second quarter 2005, Alabama Power issued 1,000,000 shares of common
stock to Southern Company at $40.00 a share ($40&nbsp;million aggregate purchase price). The proceeds
from the sale were used by Alabama Power for general corporate purposes.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Alabama Power did not issue or redeem any long-term securities during the third quarter of
2005. In addition to any financings that may be necessary to meet capital requirements and
contractual obligations, Alabama Power plans to continue, when economically feasible, a program to
retire higher-cost securities and
replace these obligations with lower-cost capital if market conditions permit.
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">48
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">53
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left">
<A name="147"></A>
</DIV>
<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt">THIRD QUARTER 2005 vs. THIRD QUARTER 2004<BR>
AND<BR>
YEAR-TO-DATE 2005 vs. YEAR-TO-DATE 2004
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>OVERVIEW</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Georgia Power operates as a vertically integrated utility providing electricity to retail customers
within its traditional service area located within the State of Georgia and to wholesale customers
in the Southeast. Many factors affect the opportunities, challenges, and risks of Georgia Power&#146;s
business of selling electricity. These factors include the ability to maintain a stable regulatory
environment, to achieve energy sales growth while containing costs, and to recover costs related to
growing demand and increasingly stringent environmental standards. In addition, fuel costs have
risen significantly during 2005. Georgia Power will continue to work with the Georgia PSC to enable
the timely recovery of these costs.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Georgia Power continues to focus on several key performance indicators. These indicators
include customer satisfaction, peak season equivalent forced outage rate, and return on equity.
For additional information on these indicators, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151;
OVERVIEW &#151; &#147;Key Performance Indicators&#148; of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Earnings</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Georgia Power&#146;s net income after dividends on preferred stock for the third quarter and
year-to-date 2005 was $355.2&nbsp;million and $655.1&nbsp;million, respectively, compared to $287.4&nbsp;million
and $586.9&nbsp;million, respectively, for the corresponding periods in 2004. The $67.8&nbsp;million and
$68.2&nbsp;million increases in the third quarter and year-to-date 2005, respectively, over the
corresponding periods in 2004 were primarily due to higher retail base revenues resulting from the
retail rate increase effective January&nbsp;1, 2005, as well as warmer weather in September&nbsp;2005,
partially offset by increased non-fuel operating expenses. For additional information on the rate
increase, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#151; &#147;FERC and
Georgia PSC Matters &#151; Retail Rate Case&#148; of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial
statements of Georgia Power under &#147;Retail Rate Orders&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K.
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">54
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Retail revenues. </I>The chart below reflects the primary drivers of the 30.2% and 16.6%
increases in retail revenues in the third quarter and year-to-date 2005, respectively, compared to
the corresponding periods in 2004. Excluding fuel cost recovery revenues, which generally do not
affect net income, retail sales revenue increased by $192.8&nbsp;million, or 19.3%, and $282.2&nbsp;million,
or 11.3%, in the third quarter and year-to-date 2005, respectively, compared to the same periods in
the prior year, primarily due to the retail rate increase effective January&nbsp;1, 2005 and warmer
temperatures in September&nbsp;2005. See Note 3 to the financial statements of Georgia Power under
&#147;Retail Rate Orders&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information on the rate increase.
In the third quarter 2005, kilowatt-hour energy sales to residential and commercial customers were
up by 10.4% and 11.3%, respectively. Year-to-date 2005 kilowatt-hour energy sales to residential
and commercial customers increased by 1.1% and 5.9%, respectively. These increases are primarily
attributed to the warmer temperatures in September&nbsp;2005. Additionally, the increases in commercial
kilowatt-hour energy sales are also attributed to sustained economic strength, customer growth of
2.4%, and a reclassification of customers from industrial to commercial to be consistent with the
rate structure approved by the Georgia PSC when compared to the corresponding periods in 2004.
During the third quarter and year-to-date 2005, kilowatt-hour energy sales to industrial customers
decreased by 4.2% and 4.1%, respectively, primarily as a result of this reclassification of
customers.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Details of retail revenues are as follows:
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><DIV style="border-bottom: 1px solid #000000; font-size: 1px">&nbsp;</DIV>
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">55
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Sales for resale &#151; non-affiliates. </I>Energy revenues from sales for resale to non-affiliates
increased $64.2&nbsp;million and $142.2&nbsp;million, respectively, in the third quarter and year-to-date
2005 compared to the same periods in 2004 as a result of a 22.3% and 22.2% increase, respectively,
in price and a 152.1% and 94.6% increase, respectively, in kilowatt-hour sales. The 2005 price
increases are generally the result of increasing fuel costs. The kilowatt-hour sales increases are
primarily a result of new contracts with non-affiliated customers effective in January&nbsp;2005 which
increased the demand for energy. Energy sales do not have a significant impact on earnings since
energy is usually sold at variable cost. The capacity component of these transactions increased
$18.3&nbsp;million and $54.9&nbsp;million in the third quarter and year-to-date 2005, respectively, over the
corresponding periods in 2004.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Sales for resale &#151; affiliates and Purchased power expense &#151; affiliates. </I>Energy sales to and
purchases from affiliated companies within the Southern Company system will vary depending on
demand and the availability and cost of generating resources at each company. These sales and
purchases are made in accordance with the IIC, as approved by the FERC. These transactions did not
have a significant impact on earnings since this energy is generally sold at marginal cost and
energy purchases are generally offset by energy revenues through Georgia Power&#146;s fuel cost recovery
clause. The third quarter 2005 increase in purchased power from affiliates is primarily due to a
61.1% increase in the cost of fuel. Year-to-date 2005, purchased power from affiliates increased
when compared to the same period in 2004 by $30.3&nbsp;million primarily as a result of additional
capacity expenses under PPAs with Southern Power that went into effect in June&nbsp;2004. See Note 7 to
the financial statements of Georgia Power under &#147;Purchased Power Commitments&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form
10-K for additional information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Other revenues</I>. In the third quarter and year-to-date 2005, other revenues increased when
compared with the corresponding periods in 2004 primarily as a result of $6.0&nbsp;million and $8.3
million, respectively, of higher transmission revenues, $1.6&nbsp;million and $4.0&nbsp;million,
respectively, of higher customer fees that went into effect January&nbsp;2005, and $1.2&nbsp;million and $4.3
million, respectively, of higher outdoor lighting revenues.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Fuel expense</I>. Fuel expense increased in the third quarter and year-to-date 2005 primarily as
a result of an increase in the average cost of fuel per net kilowatt-hour generated of 41.6% and
28.8%, respectively, when compared to the corresponding periods in 2004 due to higher coal and
natural gas prices. These expenses do not have a significant impact on earnings since fuel
expenses are generally offset by fuel revenues through Georgia Power&#146;s fuel cost recovery clause.
See FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#151; &#147;FERC and Georgia PSC Matters &#151; Retail Fuel Cost Recovery&#148; and
Note (J)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for additional information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Purchased power expense &#151; non-affiliates. </I>Purchased power expense &#151; non-affiliates was
higher in the third quarter 2005 due to an increase in purchases to meet higher demand and a 157%
increase in the cost of fuel and in year-to-date 2005 due to a 52.1% increase in the cost of fuel
due to higher natural gas prices. These expenses do not have a significant impact on earnings
since energy expenses are generally offset by energy revenues through Georgia Power&#146;s fuel cost
recovery clause.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Other
operations expense. </I>Other operations expense increased in the third quarter and year-to-date
2005 by $49.6&nbsp;million and $55.9&nbsp;million, respectively, primarily due to increased employee labor costs and benefits of
$27.0&nbsp;million and $38.7&nbsp;million, respectively, and litigation expenses of $1.7&nbsp;million and $2.6
million, respectively. Such increases for both the third quarter and year-to-date 2005 were
partially offset by increased billings of approximately $7.5&nbsp;million to Georgia Power&#146;s affiliates
for hurricane assistance when compared to the prior year.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">56
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Depreciation and amortization expense. </I>Depreciation and amortization expenses in the third
quarter and year-to-date 2005 were higher when compared to the corresponding periods in the prior
year mainly due to the expiration in 2004 of certain provisions in Georgia Power&#146;s three-year
retail rate plan ending December&nbsp;31, 2004 (2001 Retail Rate Plan). In accordance with the 2001
Retail Rate Plan, Georgia Power amortized an accelerated cost recovery liability as a credit to
amortization expense and recognized new Georgia PSC-certified purchased power costs in rates evenly
over the three years ended December&nbsp;31, 2004. This treatment resulted in a credit to amortization
expense of $47&nbsp;million and $140&nbsp;million, respectively, during the third quarter and year-to-date
2004. See Note 3 to the financial statements of Georgia Power under &#147;Retail Rate Orders&#148; in Item&nbsp;8
of the Form 10-K for additional information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Taxes other than income taxes. </I>The increases in taxes other than income taxes for the third
quarter and year-to-date 2005 are attributed primarily to higher municipal gross receipts taxes of
$9.1&nbsp;million and $12.9&nbsp;million, respectively, resulting from increased operating revenues.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Interest expense, net of amounts capitalized</I>. The third quarter and year-to-date 2005
increases in interest expense, net of amounts capitalized mainly result from the issuance of
additional senior notes in the first half of 2005, and from higher interest rates on variable rate
debt. See FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#151; &#147;Financing Activities&#148; herein for additional
information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Other income (expense), net</I>. The third quarter and year-to-date 2005 increases in other
income (expense), net compared to the corresponding periods in 2004 relate primarily to $11.8
million of gas hedge gains in September&nbsp;2005. See Note 3 to the financial statements of Georgia
Power under &#147;Retail Fuel Hedging Program&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information on these
hedges and the sharing of financial gains with retail customers. Also see FINANCIAL CONDITION AND
LIQUIDITY &#151; &#147;Market Price Risk&#148; herein for information on hedges outstanding as of September&nbsp;30,
2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The results of operations discussed above are not necessarily indicative of Georgia Power&#146;s future
earnings potential. The level of Georgia Power&#146;s future earnings depends on numerous factors that
affect the opportunities, challenges, and risks of Georgia Power&#146;s business of selling electricity.
These factors include Georgia Power&#146;s ability to maintain a stable regulatory environment, to
achieve energy sales growth while containing costs, and to recover costs related to growing demand
and increasingly stringent environmental standards. Future earnings in the near term will depend,
in part, upon growth in energy sales which is subject to a number of factors. These factors
include weather, competition, new energy contracts with neighboring utilities, energy conservation
practiced by customers, the price of electricity, the price elasticity of demand, and the rate of
economic growth in Georgia Power&#146;s service area. For additional information relating to these
issues, see BUSINESS &#151; The SOUTHERN System &#151; &#147;Risk Factors&#148; in Item&nbsp;1 and MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION
AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Environmental Matters</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Compliance costs related to the Clean Air Act and other environmental regulations could affect
earnings if such costs cannot be fully recovered in rates on a timely basis. For additional
information, including information on certain environmental litigation, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION
AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#151; &#147;Environmental Matters&#148; of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;7 and
Note 3 to the financial statements of Georgia Power under &#147;New Source Review Actions&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of
the Form 10-K.
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">57
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>New Source Review Actions</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On June&nbsp;24, 2005, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit upheld, in part,
the EPA&#146;s December&nbsp;2002 revisions to its new source review (NSR)&nbsp;regulations, which included
changes to the regulatory exclusions and methods of calculating emissions increases. However, the
court vacated portions of those revisions, including those addressing the exclusion of certain
pollution control projects. On October&nbsp;20, 2005, the EPA published a proposed rule clarifying the
test for determining when an emissions increase is subject to the NSR requirements. The impact of
the proposed rules will depend on adoption of the final rules by the EPA and the individual state
implementation of such rules, as well as the outcome of any additional legal challenges, and,
therefore, cannot be determined at this time.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Plant Wansley Environmental Litigation</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In March&nbsp;2005, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit accepted Georgia Power&#146;s petition
for review of the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Georgia&#146;s December&nbsp;15, 2004
order related to the Plant Wansley environmental litigation. Oral argument is scheduled for early
2006. The ultimate outcome of this matter cannot now be determined. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION
AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#151; &#147;Environmental Matters &#151; Plant Wansley Environmental
Litigation&#148; of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements of Georgia Power
under &#147;Plant Wansley Environmental Litigation&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note (B)&nbsp;to the
Condensed Financial Statements herein under &#147;Plant Wansley Environmental Litigation&#148; for additional
information.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Carbon Dioxide Litigation</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#151; &#147;Environmental Matters &#151;
Carbon Dioxide Litigation&#148; of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for information on a
complaint filed by attorneys general from eight states, each outside of Southern Company&#146;s service
territory, and the corporation counsel for New York City in July&nbsp;2004 against Southern Company and
four other electric power companies alleging that the companies&#146; emissions of carbon dioxide, a
greenhouse gas, contribute to global warming, which the plaintiffs assert is a public nuisance. A
nearly identical complaint was filed by three environmental groups in the same court. In September
2005, the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York dismissed these cases. The
plaintiffs filed an appeal on October&nbsp;19, 2005. The ultimate outcome of this matter cannot be
determined at this time.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Other Environmental Matters</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The EPA issued the final Clean Air Interstate Rule on March&nbsp;10, 2005. The rule addresses sulfur
dioxide (SO<SUB>2</SUB>) and nitrogen oxide (NO<SUB>x</SUB>) emissions that contribute to
nonattainment of the eight-hour ozone and fine particulate matter National Ambient Air Quality
Standards. Twenty-eight eastern states, including the State of Georgia, are subject to the fine
particulate matter and/or the eight-hour ozone requirements set forth within the rule. The rule
may require additional reductions of SO<SUB>2 </SUB>and/or NO<SUB>x</SUB> to be achieved by the
installation of additional controls at Georgia Power&#146;s coal-fired facilities or through the
purchase of allowances.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On March&nbsp;15, 2005, the EPA announced the final Clean Air Mercury Rule, selecting a
cap-and-trade approach to be implemented in two phases, 2010 and 2018. The rule sets a permanent
cap on emissions at the 2018 level and provides for an emissions allowance trading market.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">58
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On June&nbsp;15, 2005, the EPA issued final rules addressing Best Available Retrofit Technology
(BART)&nbsp;standards under the Regional Haze Program. States must develop regulations to implement the
federal regional haze requirements, including BART standards, by December&nbsp;17, 2007.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On June&nbsp;14 and 15, 2005, the EPA published final rules approving the redesignation of the
Atlanta metro area to &#147;attainment&#148; under the one-hour ground-level ozone standard. On June&nbsp;15,
2005, the EPA revoked the one-hour ground-level ozone standard, in connection with the
implementation of its new eight-hour ozone standard.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On September&nbsp;8, 2005, the EPA proposed a rule for the implementation of the fine particulate
matter air quality standard. Several areas within Georgia Power&#146;s service area were previously
designated by the EPA as &#147;nonattainment&#148; for the standard. The EPA plans to finalize the proposed
implementation rule in 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The impact of these rules on Georgia Power will depend on the outcome of legal challenges and
development and implementation of applicable state regulations and therefore cannot be determined
at this time.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>FERC and Georgia PSC Matters</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Market-Based Rate Authority</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"> </FONT>&#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#151; &#147;FERC and
Georgia PSC Matters &#151; Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the
financial statements of Georgia Power under &#147;Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form
10-K for information on the FERC&#146;s April&nbsp;2004 order adopting a new interim analysis for measuring
generation market power and a proceeding initiated by the FERC in December&nbsp;2004 to assess Southern
Company&#146;s generation dominance within its retail service territory. Georgia Power has
authorization from the FERC to sell power to non-affiliates at market-based prices. Georgia Power,
through SCS as agent, also has FERC authority to make short-term opportunity sales at market rates.
Specific FERC approval must be obtained with respect to a market-based contract with an affiliate.
On February&nbsp;15, 2005, Southern Company submitted additional information related to generation
dominance in its retail service territory. A hearing before an administrative law judge to review
the February filing is scheduled for March&nbsp;2006. Any new market-based rate transactions in
Southern Company&#146;s retail service territory entered into after February&nbsp;27, 2005 will be subject to
refund to the level of the default cost-based rates, pending the outcome of the proceeding. In the
event that the FERC&#146;s default mitigation measures are ultimately applied, Georgia Power may be
required to charge cost-based rates for certain wholesale sales in the Southern Company retail
service territory, which may be lower than negotiated market-based rates. The impact of such sales
through September&nbsp;30, 2005 is not material to Georgia Power&#146;s net income. The final outcome of
this matter will depend on the form in which the final methodology for assessing generation market
power and mitigation rules may be ultimately adopted and cannot be determined at this time.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition, in May&nbsp;2005, the FERC started an investigation to determine whether Southern
Company satisfies the other three parts of the FERC&#146;s market-based rate analysis: transmission
market power, barriers to entry, and affiliate abuse or reciprocal dealing. The FERC established a
new refund period related to this expanded investigation. Any and all new market-based rate
transactions involving any Southern Company subsidiary will be subject to refund to the extent the
FERC orders lower rates as a result of this new investigation, with the refund period beginning
July&nbsp;19, 2005. The FERC also directed that this expanded
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">59
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">proceeding be held in abeyance pending the outcome of the proceeding on the IIC discussed below.
The impact of such sales through September&nbsp;30, 2005 is not material to Georgia Power&#146;s net income.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Southern Company and its subsidiaries believe that there is no meritorious basis for these
allegations and intend to vigorously defend themselves in the proceeding. However, the final
outcome of this matter, including any remedies to be applied in the event of an adverse ruling in
this proceeding, cannot now be determined.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Intercompany Interchange Contract</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Also, in May&nbsp;2005, the FERC initiated a new proceeding to examine (1)&nbsp;the provisions of the IIC
among Alabama Power, Georgia Power, Gulf Power, Mississippi Power, Savannah Electric, Southern
Power, and SCS, as agent, under the terms of which the power pool of Southern Company is operated,
and, in particular, the propriety of the continued inclusion of Southern Power as a party to the
IIC, (2)&nbsp;whether any parties to the IIC have violated the FERC&#146;s standards of conduct applicable to
utility companies that are transmission providers, and (3)&nbsp;whether Southern Company&#146;s code of
conduct defining Southern Power as a &#147;system company&#148; rather than a &#147;marketing affiliate&#148; is just
and reasonable. In connection with the formation of Southern Power, the FERC authorized Southern
Power&#146;s inclusion in the IIC in 2000. The FERC also previously approved Southern Company&#146;s code of
conduct. The FERC order directs that the administrative law judge who presided over the McIntosh
PPA proceeding be assigned to preside over the hearing in this proceeding and that the testimony
and exhibits presented in that proceeding be preserved to the extent appropriate. The hearing is
scheduled for June&nbsp;2006. See Note 3 to the financial statements of Georgia Power under &#147;Plant
McIntosh Construction Project&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for further information on the McIntosh
PPA proceeding. Effective July&nbsp;19, 2005, revenues from transactions under the IIC involving any
Southern Company subsidiaries will be subject to refund to the extent the FERC orders any changes
to the IIC.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Southern Company and its subsidiaries believe that there is no meritorious basis for these
allegations and intend to vigorously defend themselves in the proceeding. However, the final
outcome of this matter, including any remedies to be applied in the event of an adverse ruling in
this proceeding, cannot now be determined.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Generation Interconnection Agreements</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#151; &#147;FERC and Georgia PSC
Matters &#151; Generation Interconnection Agreements&#148; of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for
information on the FERC&#146;s Order 2003 related to standardization of generation interconnection
agreements and procedures. The FERC has indicated that Order 2003, which was effective January&nbsp;20,
2004, is to be applied prospectively to interconnection agreements. Subsidiaries of Tenaska, Inc., as
counterparties to previously executed interconnection agreements with Georgia Power and another
Southern Company subsidiary, have filed complaints at the FERC requesting that the FERC modify the
agreements and that Georgia Power refund a total of $7.9&nbsp;million previously paid for
interconnection facilities, with interest. Georgia Power has opposed such relief, and the
proceedings are still pending. The impact of Order 2003 and its subsequent rehearings on Georgia
Power and the final results of these matters cannot be determined at this time.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Retail Fuel Cost Recovery</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On May&nbsp;17, 2005, the Georgia PSC voted to allow Georgia Power to increase customer fuel rates to
recover estimated under recovered fuel costs of approximately $508&nbsp;million as of May&nbsp;31, 2005 over
the period from June&nbsp;1, 2005 through May&nbsp;31, 2009, as well as future projected fuel costs based on
a June&nbsp;2005 through May&nbsp;2006 test period. The new fuel rate became effective June&nbsp;1, 2005 and
represents an average annual increase in
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">60
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">customer billings of approximately 9.5%, or approximately $473&nbsp;million. Based on the order, a
portion of the under-recovered regulatory clause revenues was reclassified from current assets to
deferred charges and other assets on the balance sheet. Under recovered fuel amounts for the
period subsequent to June&nbsp;1, 2005 totaled $198.3&nbsp;million through September&nbsp;30, 2005. In accordance
with the Georgia PSC&#146;s order, such amounts will be reviewed semi-annually beginning February&nbsp;2006.
If the amount under or over recovered exceeds $50&nbsp;million at the evaluation date, Georgia Power
will be required to file for a temporary fuel rate change. However, Georgia Power has agreed with
a Georgia PSC staff recommendation to suspend the temporary fuel rate provision and, instead, will
file a request no later than April&nbsp;2006 to increase its fuel cost recovery rate. Fuel cost
recovery revenues as recorded on the financial statements are adjusted for differences in actual
recoverable costs and amounts billed in current regulated rates. Accordingly, any increase in the
billing factor would have no significant effect on Georgia Power&#146;s revenues or net income, but
would increase annual cash flow. See Note 3 to the financial statements of Georgia
Power under &#147;Fuel Cost Recovery&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note (J)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial
Statements herein for additional information.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Other Matters</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In July&nbsp;2005, the U.S. Congress passed the Energy Policy Act of 2005 (Energy Act), which President
Bush signed into law in August&nbsp;2005. Among other things, the Energy Act includes various tax
subsidies for electric utilities and provisions repealing the PUHCA. The Energy Act also amends
federal energy laws and provides the FERC with new oversight responsibilities for the electric
utility industry. The implementation of the Energy Act requires proceedings at the state level and
the development of regulations by the FERC, as well as other federal agencies. Georgia Power is
reviewing the legislation. Its impacts will depend on the promulgation and implementation of final
rules and cannot be determined at this time.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Georgia Power is subject to certain claims and legal actions arising in the ordinary course of
business. In addition, Georgia Power&#146;s business activities are subject to extensive governmental
regulation related to public health and the environment. Litigation over environmental issues and
claims of various types, including property damage, personal injury, and citizen enforcement of
environmental requirements, has increased generally throughout the United States. In particular,
personal injury claims for damages caused by alleged exposure to hazardous materials have become
more frequent. The ultimate outcome of such litigation against Georgia Power cannot be predicted at
this time; however, management does not anticipate that the liabilities, if any, arising from such
current proceedings would have a material adverse effect on Georgia Power&#146;s financial statements.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See the Notes to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for discussion of various other
contingencies, regulatory matters, and other matters being litigated which may affect future
earnings potential.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>ACCOUNTING POLICIES</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Georgia Power prepares its financial statements in accordance with accounting principles generally
accepted in the United States. Significant accounting policies are described in Note 1 to the
financial statements of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. In the application of these
policies, certain estimates are made that may have a material impact on Georgia Power&#146;s results of
operations and related disclosures. Different assumptions and measurements could produce estimates
that are significantly different from those recorded in the financial
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">61
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
